title: How to Design Tops and Dresses

steps.headline: Put on some music if that helps you think, or even watch a fashion program to help you decide what style you want.
steps.description: You could even flip through a fashion magazine (Chatelaine, Elle, and Cosmopolitan are great) for ideas.

steps.headline: Collect your supplies and decide if you are going to draw a sleeveless, long, short, spaghetti strap, strapless, or three quarter length sleeve (long sleeve and strapless are simple).
Make sure you're drawing on lined paper so you have guidelines and a better sense of proportion.
steps.description: Later, you can draw the sketch on plain paper.

steps.headline: Start with a basic shoulder sketch.
steps.description: It doesn't have to be fancy -- you can always go back and fix things later. Right now, your goal is to get your idea on paper. Details come afterwards.

steps.headline: Draw a curved line.
steps.description: This will be the top of your top/dress.

steps.headline: Then draw two thin lines coming down for the corners.
Go down the page where the waist will be and do a slight inward curve to show that the model has a figure.
steps.description: Have a figure so it's more fitted. Fitted outfits are more flattering than clothes that hang on you like a sack. You can draw sack like baggy clothes if you want to.

steps.headline: Do the bottom of your top/dress however you want.
steps.description: You could make it long or short, lacy or regular, hemmed or not hemmed, angled or straight.
